American from Galveston who was in Germany when war broke out. He became a U-boat sailor and is now a Sparticide leader. He carries his pistols in a lawyers portfolio
Verso: American from Galveston who was in Germany when war broke out. He became a U-boat sailor and is now a Sparticide leader. He carries his pistols in a lawyers portfolio

Note: L.T. and an Italian General standing before the famous wooden idol of Von Hindenburg, in Berlin. This mammoth statue of the Field Marshal was hurled down a few days later during the German revolution. At this particular time L.T. was preparing a historical record of the Spartacus revolt in Germany

L.T. and an Italian General standing before the famous wooden idol of Von Hindenburg, in Berlin. This mammoth statue of the Field Marshal was hurled down a few days later during the German revolution. At this particular time L.T. was preparing a historical record of the Spartacus revolt in Germany

Note: L.T. (on the right), in front of famous giant wooden image of Hindenburg. Picture taken during the German Revolution, just before the celebrated statue was demolished; Verso: The Hindenburg Idol

WITH LAWRENCE IN ARABIA . In late 1917, Lowell Thomas, American war correspondent, went to the Middle East to cover the Arab Revolt against the Turks, led by a young Englishman, Col. T.E. Lawrence, the most romantic and most contradictory figure of his era. Now that Sam Spiegel and David Lean are bringing to the screen the story of "Lawrence of Arabia" , with Peter O'Toole in the title role, surrounded by an all-star cast, the pictures taken by Lowell Thomas and his photographer, Harry Chase, have special significance. Thomas's own captions are used here. LTh-17 Colonel Lawrence conferring with Commander D.G. Hogarth, one of his advisers at the Arab Bureau of Cairo

Note: "WITH LAWRENCE IN ARABIA" . In late 1917, Lowell Thomas, American war correspondent, went to the Middle East to cover the Arab Revolt against the Turks, led by a young Englishman, Col. T.E. Lawrence, the most romantic and most contradictory figure of his era. Now that Sam Spiegel and David Lean are bringing to the screen the story of "Lawrence of Arabia" , with Peter O'Toole in the title role, surrounded by an all-star cast, the pictures taken by Lowell Thomas and his photographer, Harry Chase, have special significance. Thomas's own captions are used here. LTh-17 Colonel Lawrence conferring with Commander D.G. Hogarth, one of his advisers at the Arab Bureau of Cairo

WITH LAWRENCE IN ARABIA . In late 1917, Lowell Thomas, American war correspondent, went to the Middle East to cover the Arab Revolt against the Turks, led by a young Englishman, Col. T.E. Lawrence, the most romantic and most contradictory figure of his era. Now that Sam Spiegel and David Lean are bringing to the screen the story of "Lawrence of Arabia", with Peter O'Toole in the title role, surrounded by an all-star cast, the pictures taken by Lowell Thomas and his photographer, Harry Chase, have special significance. Thomas's own captions are used here; LTh-21 Feisal and Lawrence (far right, seated) conferring with Bedouin sheikhs

Note: "WITH LAWRENCE IN ARABIA" . In late 1917, Lowell Thomas, American war correspondent, went to the Middle East to cover the Arab Revolt against the Turks, led by a young Englishman, Col. T.E. Lawrence, the most romantic and most contradictory figure of his era. Now that Sam Spiegel and David Lean are bringing to the screen the story of "Lawrence of Arabia", with Peter O'Toole in the title role, surrounded by an all-star cast, the pictures taken by Lowell Thomas and his photographer, Harry Chase, have special significance. Thomas's own captions are used here; LTh-21 Feisal and Lawrence (far right, seated) conferring with Bedouin sheikhs

Snapshot of L.T. taken standing on one of the lofty peaks of the Italian Alps, in mid-winter. The temperature is below zero most of the time. This was when he was with an Italian regiment on skis. The war in the High Alps was being fought from mountain peak to mountain peak

Subject files: Malta

Admiral Lord Calthorpe, 2nd British Sea Lord, on the roof of his headquarters on the Island of Malta. L.T.'s ship enroute to Palestine was chased into Malta by U-boats. Lord Calthorpe is explaining his defenses to L.T. The officer on the right is Lt. Com. Chas. Dickens, grandson of the novelist

Verso: Admiral Lord Calthorpe, 2nd British Sea Lord, on the roof of his headquarters on the Island of Malta. L.T.'s ship enroute to Palestine was chased into Malta by U-boats. Lord Calthorpe is explaining his defenses to L.T. The officer on the right is Lt. Com. Chas. Dickens, grandson of the novelist

Subject files: Lowell Thomas

It has taken Lowell Thomas 51 years of broadcasting, many more in public speaking, scores of files and 52 books to tell the things has seen and done from Allenby at Jerusalem and Lawrence in Arabia to Shangria and Timbuktu with thousands of points in between. Thomas is shown during interview with UPI 5/7. In background is a painting of (T.E.) Lawrence in Arabia; Please credit United Press International Photo

Verso: It has taken Lowell Thomas 51 years of broadcasting, many more in public speaking, scores of files and 52 books to tell the things has seen and done from Allenby at Jerusalem and Lawrence in Arabia to Shangria and Timbuktu with thousands of points in between. Thomas is shown during interview with UPI 5/7. In background is a painting of (T.E.) Lawrence in Arabia; Please credit United Press International Photo

Frances Thomas wearing helmet. GERMANY OF TODAY. Parade helmet of the Kaiser - taken by a Spartacus soldier during the riot in the Kaiser's Palace, when all of his uniforms were taken by the soldiers. Lowell Thomas, American War Correspondent, was quickly on the spot and bought this interesting souvenir from the soldier and brought it with him to New York

Verso: Frances Thomas wearing helmet. GERMANY OF TODAY. Parade helmet of the Kaiser - taken by a Spartacus soldier during the riot in the Kaiser's Palace, when all of his uniforms were taken by the soldiers. Lowell Thomas, American War Correspondent, was quickly on the spot and bought this interesting souvenir from the soldier and brought it with him to New York

L.T. with his ubiquitous Stetson hat, looking up at one of the huge protector pads hanging before one of the exquisitely carved entrances on the Cathedral of St. Mark's, in Venice.
